Award.AbstractNarration:
Thurston's Geometrization conjecture prompted the study of one of the main objects in topology, a manifold, from a new perspective: using geometry. Soon it was noticed that hyperbolic manifolds formed the largest and the least understood class of manifolds. Informally, a hyperbolic 3-manifold is an object modeled locally on 3-dimensional space that has hyperbolic metric. An important subclass of such manifolds are knot and link complements in 3-sphere. Additionally, knots and links are an object of study on their own, and knot theory has a number of applications in pure mathematics, as well as in applied fields of study. A knot is easy to draw as a planar diagram with information about underpasses/overpasses at crossings. However, establishing the connection between the diagram and geometric properties of the corresponding 3-manifold is a hard task. This is the first main goal of the proposal. The other goal is exploring the relation between geometric invariants and invariants that come from other areas of mathematics. The PI is engaged in mentoring student research and developing software that helps to use the geometric perspective, and will continue these activities.

With M. Thistlethwaite, the PI made progress towards the first goal by suggesting a new method for computing the hyperbolic structure directly from a link diagram. With W. Neumann, she generalized this approach to parameterize hyperbolic structure of a cusped 3-manifold. This project blends the new method with various techniques for a systematic study of the intrinsic geometry of hyperbolic links and its connection with a combinatorial picture. Among the open problems considered are questions about the canonical cell decomposition, hyperbolic volume, lengths of various arcs, geometric triangulations, etc. While these questions are interesting a priori, a significant part of the project is concerned with immediate applications of the geometric insight obtained. For example, the PI will explore the relation between geometric and quantum link invariants, investigate the connection between the geometry and arithmetic invariants of hyperbolic 3-manifolds, approach tangle tabulation using geometry and computer calculations, and tackle some other open questions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A link consists of loops embedded in space. A 3-sphere is a generalization of a usual 2-sphere, one dimension up. Such a sphere minus a link is a 3-dimensional manifold. Locally, it reminds of 3-dimensional Euclidean space, but has various interesting properties.

Links and 3-manifolds are used in physics (e.g. relativity theory or statistical mechanics), biology, chemistry, engineering, computer science and mathematics.

Intellectual Merit. Many 3-manifolds, and knot and link complements in particular, are hyperbolic due to Hyperbolization Theorem by William Thurston. It means that locally these spaces have constant negative curvature -1, similarly to the surface of a saddle. They also have hyperbolic metric, and this metric is unique due Rigidity Theorem by Mostow and Prasad. Therefore there are numerous invariants of hyperbolic links. Not all links are hyperbolic, but the geometry and topology of other types of links are better understood. At the same time, for hyperbolic links, there are many open questions on how the invariants and their properties relate to a simple picture of a link. For example, to prove a theorem about geometric properties of all links with certain diagrams can be a hard task.

The first goal of this proposal was to obtain an insight into this. We developed new techniques allowing to work with geometric properties and invariants of hyperbolic links, and often to “read” them off a knot diagram. We used these techniques to prove results about the geometry of topological (crossing) arcs, ideal geodesic triangulations, gave the method to compute exact hyperbolic volume of links from their diagrams, improved bounds on volume in terms of the number of twists of the diagram, bounded a number of surfaces in link complements and investigated their properties. The second goal was to better understand the connections of geometry and topology of links with other areas of mathematics. We explored properties of invariant trace field (an invariant related to hyperbolic geometry and number theory), developed a new method to compute character variety of a knot from its diagram (an object from algebraic geometry), established further connections with quantum topology through colored Jones polynomial, and proved that many problems in knot theory are NP-hard (a theorem on the interface of computational complexity theory and knot theory). All this resulted in seven papers, two preprints, and two software packages authored/co-authored by the PI. Additionally, the postdocs and students supervised by the PI in the duration of the grant also produced papers and software.

Broader Impacts. The grant did not request support for students or postdocs. But in the duration of the grant the PI worked with high school students, has been a research supervisor to 4 undergraduate students, an advisor to 1 PhD student, a faculty supervisor to 5 mathematicians at postdoctoral level, and a career mentor to a PhD student through the Association of Women Mathematics (AWM) program. Some of this activity resulted in research preprints, while some of it had emphasis on educating the students about this research area. The PI also co-organized 4 international conferences, 2 AMS special sessions, as well as regular seminars and colloquia. The PI developed and taught or co-taught multiple graduate courses and one undergraduate course in this area of study, and gave about 50 talks on her research results. The PI has also been actively promoting participation of women, who are underrepresented in geometry and topology, through giving research talks at related events (e.g. AWM events) and through having female mentees.
